subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Common Workplace Hazards for Lone Working
headline: Discover the twelve most-common workplace hazards and ways to manage them in this free online course.
description: This short course will assist employers, employees and supervisors in identifying and managing common workplace hazards. We examine dangers posed by digital screen equipment, manual handling and working alone. In addition, you will discover the proposed legal requirements set by the Health and Safety Executive of the U.K. for managing these hazards. This course will give you an understanding of the legal aspect of workplace hazards.
courseDescription:
Discussions about workplace hazards often overlook hazards associated with digital screen equipment, manual handling and lone working. This course will discuss these important yet commonly overlooked categories of workplace hazards to help employers, employees, and supervisors identify and manage them accordingly, making this course unique!

This short course, designed by Exoexcellence Consultants, is divided into three distinct topics, each dedicated to a critical hazard category. By completing these topics, you will be able to identify these workplace hazards and their associated risks and manage them effectively. In addition, this course contains graphics and statistics to help commit this knowledge to memory.

Besides the above, we will go over the legal considerations and requirements for each of the concerned hazards. We have taken these conditions from the Health and Safety Executive of the United Kingdom. We have included them to help you gain insight into how to abide by existing laws when dealing with workplace hazards. The course also contains a summary to help you review the critical points. Lastly, you will complete a brief assessment before qualifying for the Alison certificate.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Analyze the hazards associated with Display Screen Equipment
    • Outline the hazards associated with Display Screen Equipment and their management 
    • Recall the dangers of manual handling and its workplace management
    • Indicate the tasks involving manual handling in the workplace 
    • Explain the correct method for carrying heavy loads around the workplace
    • Outline the management activities concerned with manual handling hazards
    • Classify the two categories of lone workers
    • Define the responsibility of lone workers and their employers
    • Recognize the importance of establishing good housekeeping practices in the workplace

  • Hazards Associated with Display Screen Equipment

  • With digitalization, many industries have moved to digital equipment from analog equipment. This has
    led to increased use of DSE (Display Screen Equipment) in the workplace. The three most common hazards
    associated with DSE use are;
    • Upper Limb Disorders.
    • Back injuries due to assuming incorrect posture while sitting.
    • Eye strain due to continuous screen exposure.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Upper Limb Disorders (ULDs ) usually arise from the use of keyboards and mouse. The precautions to prevent these ULDs are:
    • A correct posture must be assumed while typing on the keyboard.
    • There must be frequent breaks while typing.

  • Lone Working

  • The Health and Safety Executive of the U.K. describes lone working as: "Lone workers are those who work by themselves without close or direct supervision."
  • Types of Lone Workers
  • Lone workers can be classified into two basic types:
    • New Tab
    • People in Fixed Establishments
    • Mobile Workers Working Away From Their Workplace 
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • People in fixed establishments usually work in small workshops and fuel stations. These include workers working in factories, research facilities, and training establishments. Lone workers working in the fixed establishment also work outside regular hours, such as janitors, cleaners, security staff, etc.
      People in fixed establishments usually work in small workshops and fuel stations. These include workers working in factories, research facilities, and training establishments. Lone workers working in the fixed establishment also work outside regular hours, such as janitors, cleaners, security staff, etc.
    • Mobile workers working away from their workspace are usually construction workers, painters, decorators, etc. Agriculture and forestry workers can also be included in this category. Other examples include engineers, estate agents, architects, etc.
      Mobile workers working away from their workspace are usually construction workers, painters, decorators, etc.  Agriculture and forestry workers can also be included in this category. Other examples include engineers, estate agents, architects, etc.
    • New Tab

    • Mobile workers working away from their workspace are usually construction workers, painters, decorators, etc. Agriculture and forestry workers can also be included in this category. Other examples include engineers, estate agents, architects, etc.
      Mobile workers working away from their workspace are usually construction workers, painters, decorators, etc.  Agriculture and forestry workers can also be included in this category. Other examples include engineers, estate agents, architects, etc.

  • Lone Working

  • The Health and Safety Executive of the U.K. describes lone working as: "Lone workers are those who work by themselves without close or direct supervision."

  • Lesson Summary

  • Hazards Associated with Display Screen Equipment
    • Upper Limb Disorders
    • Back injuries due to assuming incorrect posture while sitting
    • Eye strain due to continuous screen exposure
  • Workplace Precautions for Back Injury
    • An adjustable chair must be used while sitting and typing
    • Employees should be trained in setting up the adjustable chair
  • Management Activities for DSE
    • Supervisors must identify of workstations where DSEs are placed and take appropriate measures
    • Supervisors should identify the risks leading to ULDs in the workplace’s DSE workstation
    • Employees and employers should be trained on workplace precautions concerning ULDs and DSE
